item.title: Contract for the Provision of Facility Condition Assessments
item.description:
Merseyside Waste Disposal Authority (MWDA) is inviting tenders from suitably qualified and experience contractors to undertake Facility Condition Assessments at selected key operational facilities.
The assessment findings will provide an account of the condition of the facilities, (identifying any damage, repair, or maintenance issues), along with making recommendations for remediation works to ensure the facilities can remain in an operational condition up until 2034.

item.title: Contract for the Preliminary Contamination Risk Assessments
item.description:
Merseyside Waste Disposal Authority (MWDA) is inviting tenders from suitably qualified, experienced and registered Specialist in Land Condition (SiLC) ground investigation contractors to undertake Preliminary Contamination Risk Assessments at several of the Authority's operational waste management facilities.
MWDA's long-term waste management contract, the Waste Management and Recycling Contract (WMRC), expires in 2034 and there are a number of contractual obligations required to be undertaken prior to the expiry of the Contract. This includes a determination if any ground contamination has occurred during the life of the contract.
The sites that form MWDA's operational estate were leased to the WMRC Contractor upon its commencement in 2009. The Authority wishes to employ a suitably qualified and experienced contractor to determine and assess the potential for, or presence of, contamination associated with the operations carried out during the contractual term of the WMRC.
The Authority wishes to undertake this work in two distinct phases. First, a desk-based study to determine if the sites are at risk of additional contamination as a result of the operations undertaken throughout the duration of the WMRC.
A second intrusive phase, which will be tendered separately, will be undertaken where necessary and based on the findings of the desk study for each of the sites. This will entail the investigation, collection and analytical testing of samples as deemed necessary during the Preliminary Contamination Risk Assessment.

item.title: National Trust-NI-Lough Neagh: A Roadmap to Recovery
item.description:
The National Trust, on behalf of collaborators involved in the Forever Lough Neagh initiative, are requesting proposals for a Consultant led Multidisciplinary Team to develop a holistic, comprehensive and long - term strategic framework for Lough Neagh:  A Roadmap to Recovery . 
The Trust seeks to appoint a Multidisciplinary Consultant to undertake a strategy development process with the aim of bringing together learning from previous activities, and initiatives and projects already underway, to identify gaps in knowledge and identify actions and clear recommendations for the future. A 12-month term (1 calendar year, anticipated to commence in April 2026) will be available to complete the commission.

We are keen to work with consultants and sub-consultants that are invested in the outcomes of this project, aiming to work together to develop recommendations that will lead to a more sustainable future for Lough Neagh.  We would welcome different types of organisations and groups to come together as consortium partners to form a multi-disciplinary team to deliver this commission. We recognise the importance of local and lived knowledge and experience, and we encourage potential lead Consultants to carefully consider how teams are put together to allow for open opportunities.
The Trust seeks initial information from a range of bidders as to possible solutions, capacity, capability and relevant experience, with a view to forming a select list for a later Request for Proposal process.   

The tender is being conducted via the Proactis Plaza portal.
http://www.proactisplaza.com/
 
All tender documents are available from the Proactis Plaza Portal.

Search for The National Trust in the opportunities section and follow the instructions.

item.title: GB-Colchester: 0463(PA) Redevelopment of External Space at Trinity Square
item.description:
Colchester City Council (the Council) wishes to commission a contractor to undertake Landscape renovation of the former churchyard around the Grade I Listed Holy Trinity Church in the centre of Colchester, with access via Culver Street West.
      
      The Works will include the landscape renovation as detailed, in addition to the design and construction of New and replacement railings and gates, including handrails and Mechanical and Electrical installation.
      
      This work will be undertaken using the JCT Form of Contract - Intermediate Building Contract with Contractor's Design 2024 Edition.
      
      A Site Visit will be arranged for either the 3rd or 5th December (Exact date to be confirmed), details will be provided via clarification through the e-tendering portal.
      
      Bidders are to include their proposed timeline within the Quality response - Question 3.2Programme (Including Project Timetable & Project Management).
      
      Further details of the requirements can be found in the accompanying specification document.

item.title: Town Hall Toilet Refurbishment
item.description:
The Town Council is looking to refurbish the public toilets within the Town Hall community centre with the removal of all existing sanitary ware and a revised layout to be installed including one disabled toilet, 1 female toilet with 3 toilets and associated washbasins and 1 male toilets with 2 toilets, 2 urinals and associated washbasins. New flooring including to the entrance/foyer adjacent to the toilets.
A contract specification is included in the tender documents.
The program and scheduling will be agreed before commencement. Grant funding is being sought and this may affect the commencement. Contractors should refer to the layout document included in the tender documents.

The tender should be submitted in electronic format. 

All electronic tender documents/electronic media are to be addressed to theclerk@bawtrytowncouncil.gov.uk and annotated with "TENDER DOCUMENTS NOT TO BE OPENED BEFORE 5pm Friday 9th January 2026. The Council reserves the right to discount any tender received in contravention of this instruction. 
Tenders are to remain open for acceptance for a period of 90 days.

item.title: Market Engagement Event for the Re-Opening of the Mental Health Independence and Support Framework
item.description:
Sheffield City Council invites providers to a Market Engagement Event for the re-opening of the Mental Health Independence and Support Framework, introducing a two-tier support model:
•	Lot 1 - Standard Support: Supported accommodation and outreach for adults (18+) with severe mental illness (e.g. schizophrenia, bipolar, personality disorder) known to health/social care teams, with eligible needs under the Care Act 2014 and/or Section 117 aftercare. 
•	Lot 2 - Enhanced Support: Services for adults (18+) with severe mental illness and complex needs, including behaviours that challenge, forensic histories, neurodevelopmental conditions, and risk of harm or hospitalisation. Some of these individuals may require support with personal care tasks or medication administration.

Potential providers are invited to attend this market engagement event to learn more about the service specification and the upcoming procurement process. The Market Engagement Event will be held virtually via Microsoft Teams on Thursday 20 November 2025. Between 10.00 am - 11.30 am. If you are interested in attending this event please email adam.elwis@sheffield.gov.uk or send a message via the messaging facility on YORtender/EU Supply e-tendering platform to notify the authority of your intent to attend the event. Those who express an interest will be sent a link to attend the event.

item.title: Clinical Engineering Service - Medical Devices
item.description:
We are tendering for a clinical engineer service to support our management of medical devices across Oxford Health NHS Foundation Trust (OHFT). The contract will start from 1st April 2026 and initially run for 3 years with the option for OHFT to extend by a maximum of a further 2 years (5 years in total) with breaks in contract available at the end of year 3 and year 4. We will ask the new company to work with the incumbent company to manage a smooth transition and to start mobilisation prior to the start of the contract.

The key components of the contract include managing our master asset list, preparing new devices for use in services, servicing all medical devices at least annually in line with warranties and manufacturing requirements, responding to issues with devices from clinical teams and completing repairs with devices. As well as providing OHFT with advice as requested, which will include support with identifying new devices/models, input into clinical evaluations and an annual age/condition analysis of all devices in August of each year to support life cycle planning.

item.title: Housing Maintenance & Repair
item.description:
This dynamic purchasing system (DPS) provides a compliant, one stop shop for all aspects of housing maintenance & repair for both tenanted and void/vacant properties. Featuring a vast range of both planned and reactive maintenance & repair services, the agreement also provides access to essential compliance services such as fire safety, electrical testing & asbestos management.
 
It can help achieve Net Zero goals with PAS 2030/35 certified suppliers offering Whole Home Retrofit services and it also features Housing Portfolio Management, for customers looking to manage their housing stock and handle areas such as move ins/outs, disposals and put in place a centralised service to manage and fulfil repair requests.

item.title: Electrical - General electrical works
item.description:
•	Solar panel inverters should be inspected and maintained at least once a year by a qualified professional. This annual check-up is to ensure the inverter is functioning correctly, identify potential issues early, and prevent costly repairs. A more frequent inspection (e.g., bi-annually) may be necessary in some areas of the WRC which will be left to the discretion of the inspector. This is based on potential high pollution levels and weather conditions on the roof. 
•	Manufacturer's specific recommendations for our inverter models should always be referred to and referenced in documentation, as they may have unique guidelines for maintenance and inspection
•	All inspections and maintenance performed by qualified professionals. We request members of our in-house engineering team oversee as much of the inspections as possible so they can understand what to look for on routine inspections of these plant areas.
•	A full visual inspection of every solar panel will be needed to highlight damaged or faulty panels. 
•	As well as inspections we expect full electrical certs to be issued with each yearly inspection. 
•	We would also need a budget cost to come in the same day the solar panels are being cleaned twice a year to isolate them the process and re energise once the clean is complete. 
 This opportunity has been distributed on adamprocure.co.uk

item.title: Book Parcels and Maths Games for Children in Care
item.description:
The Service is to provide as a minimum six (6) parcels. These must be sent calendar monthly to the Virtual Schools nominated address, as identified for each eligible child. High-quality books from a range of genres, maths games and other high-quality materials, that are age appropriate to support our children's learning, which will support narrowing the gap in education achievements for our children.  We expect the Provider to demonstrate how and why materials included in a parcel are chosen. The Council support academic five hundred and thirty (530) children per year. The provider will be able to support additional children should the Council need to add new to care children to the Service each month. For those new to care children, we expect them to receive all parcels from the year.

Supply of Materials-
Staffordshire County Council invites Tenders for the provision of a Service to deliver "Educational Books and Maths Games Parcels" to eligible children in care as identified by the Staffordshire virtual school. These parcels must engage the children and young people of in reading and playing educational games through the content they provide. The Provider will supply these children with colourful parcels containing books for them to keep, maths games, stationery and other high-quality materials on a calendar monthly basis, for six (6) agreed months of the year, at an agreed start date per agreed cohort.  There will be an additional bonus parcel at Christmas. Suppliers will not be expected to provide the bonus parcel for 2025 but will be expected for the years thereafter. This brings the Total to seven (7) parcels per academic cohort.

The provider will need to have available parcels that are  split by school year groups:
•	Children aged 4-5 in the Early Years Foundation Stage/Reception 
•	Children in Year 1, (age 5-6) 
•	Children in Year 2, (ages 6-7) 
•	Children in Year 3, (ages 7-8) 
•	Children in Year 4 (ages 8-9) 
•	Children in Year 5, (ages 9-10) 
•	Children in Year 6 (ages 10-11) 
•	Children in Year 7 (ages 11-12) 


Note: If there is a child who is working at a lower or higher level, an appropriate parcel despite their school year group can be chosen. 
  
The parcel packaging will be robust to contain and transport the contents by the selected postal service be  child friendly and it should not distinguish the cohort it's intended for. The packaging must however have distinguished identification (what this is will be decided between the Provider and the Council)  to allow teachers and carers to identify the package.

The Virtual School will provide the current posting list each month to the provider upon request.

To access the tender documents and/or place a bid for the contract please visit: https://supplierlive.proactisp2p.com/Account/Login

All offers must be submitted electronically to pfruprocurement@chemonics.com

The subject line of all emails must state the tender number: PFRU2-2025-209.

The Project is tax-exempt under the Technical Assistance Framework; therefore, all prices must be quoted net of VAT.

item.title: Camden Building Repairs Contract 2: General Building Works South
item.description:
Camden Council is seeking a Contractor to support the delivery of its building repairs and maintenance related obligations which covers the Employer's housing stock of 33,000 council homes (24,000 are tenanted and 9,000 are leasehold). 

The works to be covered under this contract include the provision of:
•	 General repairs and refurbishment Works to the external envelope and common parts of buildings: repair and renewal of all major elements of construction inclusive of but not limited to windows, roofs, walls and wall coverings, drainage, glazing, damp proofing, structural works and underpinning, plumbing, painting, area lighting, emergency lighting and means of escape, including stairways, fire escapes, ladders.   
•	Underpinning
•	Concrete repair 
•	Masonry restoration
•	Steel reinforcement:.
•	Roof structure repairs
•	Timber structure repairs
•	Waterproofing and sealing
•	Facade rehabilitation
•	Internal major repairs: repairs to and, where required replacement of, kitchens, bathrooms, electrical systems, plumbing and heating.  
•	External estate works: landscaping, paths, roads, boundary walls and fencing.  

The contract will be for an initial period of three (3) years commencing on Mon 09/11/26 with the option of two (2) extensions for one (1) years each.

item.title: TD2327 - Driver Training and Assessments
item.description:
Derby City Council (The Council) is undertaking this procurement to establish a contract for the provision of driver training and assessments.

This will include professional LGV/HGV training (Category C and C + E) training and driving assessments of all drivers prior to using the DCC fleet to ensure their roadworthiness to drive the type of vehicle required as part of their role at the Council. There will also be the need for CPC (Certificate of Professional Competence) training, and specific driver related training as and when required.

The initial contract period is 3 years; the contract is estimated to commence 1 March 2026 and expire 28 February 2029. There will be an option to extend the contract for 2 years in annual increments, subject to satisfactory performance, business needs and mutual agreement. Maximum contract period is 5 years.

Prices shall be fixed for the first 12 months from the commencement date; thereafter any increment shall be once per year. Any increase will need to be submitted in writing with a clear demonstration detailing the reasoning for the price increase. Any price increase must not exceed the Consumer Price Index (CPI), and price increase will not be implemented until agreement from the Council.

For this contract, Derby City Council expects that the following changes may take place

during the contract term:

•Change in vehicle make or model - The Council may need to switch to different types or brands of vehicles during the contract.

•Fleet size changes - The number of vehicles required may increase, which could affect the overall contract cost.

oThe Council anticipate that due to the creation of the East Midlands Combined County Authority (EMCCA) there may result in changed to the council structures and service delivery For this contract it is anticipated that the effects of EMCCA may lead to an increased Fleet size and structure.

•Change in service areas - The geographical area may change, particularly if there are updates due to Local Government Reorganisation (LGR).

oLocal Government Reorganisation (LGR) is underway in several areas across the country and may result in changes to council structures, service delivery and responsibilities, and geographical coverage during the life of the contract. For this contract

it is anticipated that the effects of LGR may lead to an increased Fleet size and structure.

o The core contract value, estimated at £448,000.00, based on known current service Requirements

oAn additional estimated value of £224,000.00 to reflect potential future changes in service scope or volume linked to LGR / EMCCA. It is unknown at this stage how this value will be split.

These are not guaranteed changes but are to provide early notice to ensure they can be factored into your planning.

item.title: Resurfacing
item.description:
Chesterfield Borough Council is seeking a Contractor to maintain its corporate property throughout the Borough. This includes Chesterfield's town centre and surface car parks.

The works covered by the contract includes for repairing potholes, erecting street name plates, installation of street furniture, installation of kerbs, and resetting and repointing cobbles/Belgian setts/paving flags and any other works deemed necessary to be included in the contract.

The area of work covered by the contract is situated within the Borough of Chesterfield.

item.title: Charity Commission Digital Transformation Programme
item.description:
The Charity Commission Strategy 2024-2029 (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/charity-commission-strategy-2024-2029) sets out the ambition to embrace technological innovation and strengthen how data is used across the organisation. 

The overarching vision for the programme is to:

1) Strengthen Public Trust & Deliver Meaningful Impact
2) Create simple Services for Smarter Regulation
3) Empower People & Build Organisational Excellence

This vision will be achieved by: 

- Improving user experience for charities and their trustees 
- Using technology to enable better use of resources and expertise 
- Improving the quality of data and building trust in it 
- Being an intelligent, joined up regulator working with government departments to integrate services 

The programme goes beyond technology to a pure transformation, considering business processes and ways of working to provide a truly transformed user-centric set of services for trustees and charities across England and Wales. 

All of our digital services and casework activities are in scope of this programme, further information of these services can be found on our GOV.UK web site https://www.gov.uk/government/organisations/charity-commission/about/about-our-services 

From a technology perspective, all software runs on Microsoft Azure, and our core case management platform is built on Dynamics 365. We currently use Liferay as a Digital Experience Platform. We are building new digital service front-ends using Spring Boot. All digital services must meet GDS standards. 

The first opportunity under the programme is now open for responses, see https://redirect.contractawardservice.crowncommercial.gov.uk/digital-outcomes/opportunities/opportunity-details/project/69378  for further information.

item.title: CA16685 - RFQ 2025/36 - NMANDD PEACEPLUS Local Action Plan Cultural Programme - "World Textiles" for the Newry, Mourne and Down District Council area.
item.description:
NMANDD PEACEPLUS Local Action Plan Cultural Programme - "World Textiles" for the Newry, Mourne and Down District Council area. 

The World Textiles programme will bring together people from different backgrounds. The aim is to help them learn about textiles, fashion, and costume traditions from different cultures, including local traditions and those from around the world. 

To access this competition: 

Registered:
Login to https://suppliers.multiquote.com and view the opportunity CA16685.

Not registered:
Visit https://suppliers.multiquote.com then register and quote CA16685 as the reason for registration. 

 Any queries please contact MultiQuote on 0151 482 9230.
